content.question: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. Consider the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of y, with respect to x, equals the fraction negative y, over 4, end fraction, times the natural log of the fraction y over 50" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>50</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) A portion of the slope field for the differential equation is given below. Sketch the solution curves through the two indicated points for <math alttext="x greater than or equal to 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>≥</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text: NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION. Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit. Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point. Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> is a real number. Consider the differential equation <math alttext="the derivative of y, with respect to x, equals the fraction negative y, over 4, end fraction, times the natural log of the fraction y over 50" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>50</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) A portion of the slope field for the differential equation is given below. Sketch the solution curves through the two indicated points for <math alttext="x greater than or equal to 0" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>≥</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(b) Find <math alttext="the limit as y approaches 50, of, the derivative of y with respect to x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><munder><mrow><mi>lim</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>y</mi><mo>→</mo><mn>50</mn></mrow></munder><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(c) Let <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> be the particular solution to the differential equation with initial condition <math alttext="f of 0 equals 20" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>. Find <math alttext="f prime of 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, and explain why <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is increasing for all <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(d) For <math alttext="0 less than y, less than 40" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0</mn><mo><</mo><mi>y</mi><mo><</mo><mn>40</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>, at what value of <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> does <math alttext="the derivative of y, with respect to x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>ⅆ</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> attain its maximum value? Justify your answer.

topic.text: 1.5: Determining Limits Using Algebraic Properties of Limits

skill.text: Skill 1.C: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the classification of a given expression (e.g., Use the chain rule to find the derivative of a composite function).
